title: Bypass auth.email-domains (2)

profile.name: Phabricator
profile.about: Phabricator is a collection of open source web applications that help software companies build better software.

vulnerability_information:
This vulnerability has the same effect as my previously reported bug [#2224 Bypass `auth.email`-domains](https://hackerone.com/reports/2224), but uses a very different approach, bypassing the current fix.

Instead of truncating through length, this vulnerability uses truncation via MySQL‚Äôs (weird) behaviour on inserting Unicode characters with code points greater than `0xFFFF` into columns that have a `utf8` charset. MySQL then truncates a string as soon as it reaches such a character. For more info, see [How to support full Unicode in MySQL databases](http://mathiasbynens.be/notes/mysql-utf8mb4) by @mathias.

To replicate, register an account with following address: `attacker@gmail.comùåÜ@allowed-domain.com`.

I would suggest to reconsider not verifying email addresses as was mentioned [here](https://secure.phabricator.com/D8308#5).
vulnerability_information_html:
This vulnerability has the same effect as my previously reported bug #2224 Bypass auth.email-domains, but uses a very different approach, bypassing the current fix.

Instead of truncating through length, this vulnerability uses truncation via MySQL‚Äôs (weird) behaviour on inserting Unicode characters with code points greater than 0xFFFF into columns that have a utf8 charset. MySQL then truncates a string as soon as it reaches such a character. For more info, see How to support full Unicode in MySQL databases by @mathias.

To replicate, register an account with following address: attacker@gmail.comùåÜ@allowed-domain.com.

I would suggest to reconsider not verifying email addresses as was mentioned here.

activities.message:
This is an issue which we're aware of in general (see https://secure.phabricator.com/T1191) but had not been thinking of as a security issue until now. This represents a practical attack.

Instead of validating the email address, I'm going to attempt to filter all application input. There's no real reason to believe that the email field is the only vulnerable storage here, and the entire application assumes it will be able to load the same data it saved. Filtering all input prevents this entire class of issues.

I believe we can develop a patch to filter all HTTP input in a short period of time. We receive input from other sources as well, but they're usually trusted or harder to attack (for example, `git log` against user data in a repository), and we can harden those over time. I think we can also filter write queries before we execute them to provide an additional layer of coverage.

Let me see how practical this is. If it looks like it's not reasonable to develop a broad patch today we can apply a more tailored patch against the email field.
activities.markdown_message:
This is an issue which we're aware of in general (see https://secure.phabricator.com/T1191) but had not been thinking of as a security issue until now. This represents a practical attack.

Instead of validating the email address, I'm going to attempt to filter all application input. There's no real reason to believe that the email field is the only vulnerable storage here, and the entire application assumes it will be able to load the same data it saved. Filtering all input prevents this entire class of issues.

I believe we can develop a patch to filter all HTTP input in a short period of time. We receive input from other sources as well, but they're usually trusted or harder to attack (for example, git log against user data in a repository), and we can harden those over time. I think we can also filter write queries before we execute them to provide an additional layer of coverage.

Let me see how practical this is. If it looks like it's not reasonable to develop a broad patch today we can apply a more tailored patch against the email field.

activities.message: Some fields allow non-base-plane characters already, so filtering HTTP input on these characters may give rise to new issues. (please correct me if I'm wrong)
activities.markdown_message: Some fields allow non-base-plane characters already, so filtering HTTP input on these characters may give rise to new issues. (please correct me if I'm wrong)

activities.message: That's true, but I think there is only one case where it matters at the HTTP layer (HTML5 file data upload) and only a handful at the database layer (storing file data, storing compressed caches). In all other cases, the current behavior (usually, silent truncation of data) is worse than the new behavior will be (an explicit error). It's possible that other cases will arise, but I'd much rather break them and then add exceptions to a whitelist than discover more cases where truncation has a security impact.
activities.markdown_message: That's true, but I think there is only one case where it matters at the HTTP layer (HTML5 file data upload) and only a handful at the database layer (storing file data, storing compressed caches). In all other cases, the current behavior (usually, silent truncation of data) is worse than the new behavior will be (an explicit error). It's possible that other cases will arise, but I'd much rather break them and then add exceptions to a whitelist than discover more cases where truncation has a security impact.

activities.message:
Quick update here:

These patches add `phutil_is_utf8_with_only_bmp_characters($string)`, a function which tests if `$string` will be representable by MySQL in `utf8` columns (i.e., saving and then loading it will reproduce the original result):

https://secure.phabricator.com/D8310
https://secure.phabricator.com/D8312
https://secure.phabricator.com/D8313
https://secure.phabricator.com/D8314

This patch redefines `%s` in our query layer to mean "string which MySQL can representably store in a utf8 column", and adds `%B` for "any binary string":

https://secure.phabricator.com/D8315

This patch converts Phabricator to use `%B` and a new `CONFIG_BINARY` flag on all columns where it operates on binary data:

https://secure.phabricator.com/D8316

These patches successfully defuse the attack, as the query is now aborted during construction.

I'd also like to apply filtering at a higher level (to all HTTP inputs) but am inclined to ship this stuff first and make sure it doesn't break anything, since we aren't aware of any viable attack above the MySQL layer and I think we have no reason to believe that one exists.
activities.markdown_message:
Quick update here:

These patches add phutil_is_utf8_with_only_bmp_characters($string), a function which tests if $string will be representable by MySQL in utf8 columns (i.e., saving and then loading it will reproduce the original result):

https://secure.phabricator.com/D8310
https://secure.phabricator.com/D8312
https://secure.phabricator.com/D8313
https://secure.phabricator.com/D8314

This patch redefines %s in our query layer to mean "string which MySQL can representably store in a utf8 column", and adds %B for "any binary string":

https://secure.phabricator.com/D8315

This patch converts Phabricator to use %B and a new CONFIG_BINARY flag on all columns where it operates on binary data:

https://secure.phabricator.com/D8316

These patches successfully defuse the attack, as the query is now aborted during construction.

I'd also like to apply filtering at a higher level (to all HTTP inputs) but am inclined to ship this stuff first and make sure it doesn't break anything, since we aren't aware of any viable attack above the MySQL layer and I think we have no reason to believe that one exists.

activities.message:
I have not encountered any similar truncation behaviour in other services, so for the time being there is indeed no reason to believe similar attacks exist. And therefore, the current patches should be sufficient to mitigate a range of attacks that abuse this silent truncation of data.

Last year, [I found a vulnerability in WordPress which could lead to RCE](http://vagosec.org/2013/09/wordpress-php-object-injection/), so this behaviour could've possibly lead to much worse things in Phabricator.

activities.message:
All of that is in HEAD and seems to be working properly (in that it both prevents the issue and doesn't seem to have broken anything else). I've filed this to track the eventual filtering of all HTTP input, which I think is only a bit more involved:

https://secure.phabricator.com/T4470

activities.message: This substantially builds on #2224, but the specific mechanism also represents a separate class of issues.
activities.markdown_message: This substantially builds on #2224, but the specific mechanism also represents a separate class of issues.

activities.message: Thanks for reporting these issues, they were extremely substantive and your reports were very clear and easy to act on. Let us know if you come up with anything else!
